posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I’m seeing an unexpected behavior in the moving average filter. After being reset, the filter returns inaccurate values until it is called taps number if times. I understand why it behaves this way, but is this the intended behavior?

Here’s what I see:

Is this really the expected behavior? If so, the values from the class cannot be trusted until the number of samples is at least the number of taps .

This causes our robot to actually move in the wrong direction. In the example above, if our goal is 2 and our first reading is 4, we need to move in the negative direction. However, the filter returns 0.8 so we “correct” in the positive direction.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
The behavior comes from the assumption about what the input was at time -1, -2, -3, and -4. The wpilib implementation assumes zero, but your expect line assumes four.

This is expected behavior for filters during the first few loops of operation, when there’s not been enough information to fill them up. The solution is to init the taps to a known starting value, or use a technique other than a linear filter (perhaps just a ramp from start to finish at a defined linear rate?)

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Thanks, I understand why it behaves that way. Put simply, it sums up to 5 samples and divides the total by 5, even if there are less than 5 samples. The problem is that the average of this set {4} is 4, not .8.

The way you stated it makes sense too, but it actually seems a lot worse. It means the class makes an assumption that signals -1 through -4 are zero. Looking at it that way, why zero instead of some other arbitrary number, like 1024?

Is this really the expected behavior?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: The implementation actually seems to indicate it’s being initialized to a sum of 1 ( taps entries with a value of 1.0 / taps ).  As for “why”? Your guess is as good as mine.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I think instead of summing them and then dividing by taps, it’s multiplying each value by 1/taps and summing the result. The end result is the same.

For the set {4,2,3,11,5} it does this math: (4.0*(1.0/5.0)) + (2.0*(1.0/5.0)) + (3.0*(1.0/5.0)) + (11.0*(1.0/5.0)) + (5.0*(1.0/5.0)) = 5.0

For the set {4} the math is: (4.0*(1.0/5.0)) = .8

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Oh shoot, yeah youre 100% right. That’s just the array of gains, not the actual values.

This is what I get from trying to read code on my phone at midnight…

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
gdefender:

why zero instead of some other arbitrary number, like 1024?

Is this really the expected behavior?

I think it’s just implementation dependent. I haven’t seen a definitive source that says how moving average filters are supposed to behave on initialization (which I think is all that’s in question here).

A circuit or FPGA-based implementation (that used actual digital hardware components for each delay) or even a simple circular buffer ( DSP? C code?) might not keep track of the fact that, while there are N storage spaces, less than N are actually populated and the denominator needs to change. It would be more cost or computational expense than simply saying “Eh, for a filter of length N, the first N*Ts output is just kinda garbage let’s ignore it”.

But since this is higher level, it’s fairly cheap to re-work the implementation to have the behavior you desired. Especially since, at least per your statement, your robot’s functionality is dependent on the initialization behavior of this filter.

link_counts.title: Embedded Engineering : Moving average Digital Filter implementation TI TMS320 DSP

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: Yes, this is intended behavior. LinearFilter assumes constant feedforward and feedback gains. To give sane outputs with incomplete input, the feedforward gains would have to change during operation. That’s not doable because a LinearFilter instance returned by one of the factory functions doesn’t know what kind of filter it is.

Matlab and scipy both have functions to address this situation that solve for the filter states given past input and output.

This MATLAB function finds the initial conditions z for the delays in the transposed direct-form II filter implementation given past outputs y and inputs x.

https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.signal.lfiltic.html#scipy.signal.lfiltic

For the moving average filter (which is an FIR filter, so no feedback terms) running filter.calculate() in a loop at startup to initialize the filter states might be the most straightforward solution.

link_counts.title: Initial conditions for transposed direct-form II filter implementation - MATLAB filtic

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
calcmogul:

That’s not doable because a LinearFilter instance returned by one of the factory functions doesn’t know what kind of filter it is.

Maybe a single swiss-army class shouldn’t be responsible for implementing multiple filters.

At the very least, I think this limitation should be in the javadoc. It caused a subtle bug in our robot code that can be difficult to diagnose. I’ll open an issue.

posts.name: Bob Wolff - Janksters Team 1967
posts.cooked: My thought is to simply prime the filter ‘taps’ times with your initial value.

posts.name: Jeff Young
posts.cooked: I think you mean 4.0 initval. And, that won’t produce the values the OP said they were expecting (for calls 2-4).
